fields.description:
*NOTE: This behavior doesn't happen all the time, but it happens often (i.e. its inconsistent)*

When an EBS-backed instance with a non-root EBS volume attached, is stopped, then started again, the non-root EBS volume fails to attach.  The user then has to re-attach the volume that was attached when the EBS-backed instance was initially running.   

Per [AWS EC2 Documentation regarding _Stopping Instances_|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Stop_Start.html], the following behavior is expected:

*Instance Stop*

When you stop a running instance, the following happens:

* The instance performs a normal shutdown and stops running (the status goes to stopping and then stopped).
* The instance retains its instance ID.
* *Any Amazon EBS volumes remain attached and the data persists.*
* Any instance store volumes don't persist.
* The instance won't keep its public and private IP addresses. The exception is that instances launched in a VPC keep the same IP address when stopped and restarted.
* Any Elastic IP address mapped to the instance is unmapped. For instances launched into a VPC, the Elastic IP address remains associated with the stopped instance. When you restart the instance, the Elastic IP address is active. While the Elastic IP address is associated with the stopped instance, you're charged for the Elastic IP address.
* If you've registered the instance with a load balancer, it's likely that the load balancer won't be able to route traffic to your instance after you've stopped and restarted it. You must de-register the instance from the load balancer after stopping the instance, and then re-register after starting the instance. For more information, see De-Registering and Registering Amazon EC2 Instances section in the Elastic Load Balancing Developer Guide.
* When a Windows instance is stopped and restarted, the drive letters mapped to the attached EBS volumes are likely to change. For information on changing this default behavior, see Using EC2Config in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud Microsoft Windows Guide.

*Example*

Instance _i-ABCA3E59_ has a 25 gig root EBS volume, and a 350 EBS volume attached to it when it was running.  After stopping the instance, then re-starting it, here is the information in the NC log:

{code}

0:0D:AB:CA:3E:59 privIp=172.16.213.65 plat=linux

fields.summary: EBS-backed instances fail to attach non-root EBS volumes when restarting the instance
Add dynamic volumes to VBR on front-end when starting a stopped instance

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Pull out dynamic volumes from VBR to volumes on the NC

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.summary: Pull out dynamic volumes from VBR to volumes on the Broker

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.environment:
*non-HA*

* Frontend (CLC, Walrus, SC, CC)
* SANManager - Dell Equallogic
* 3 x NCs

comments.body: Check for this workaround as the random nature of the issue points to this as the probable cause.
I've removed the "Storage Controller" tag since this isn't an SC issue. Added "Cloud Controller" and "Broker" so this will show up in the proper filters based on component.
[~swathi] / [~zhill], what should be the proper way to verify this issue? Is running ebs test suit enough for this one?

[~shaon], I think the bfebs test suite contains the appropriate automated tests. To test it manually:
# launch an EBS backed instance
# after the instance is running, attach volume(s) to instance and verify
# stop instance
# start instance
# after the instance is running, verify that all volumes attached to the instance prior to stopping the instance continue to remain attached after instance is started

Verified. Not seeing this issue anymore.
